Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Analysis of the Water Wave Motion
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is concerned with the motion of water waves in both two and three space dimensions. The particular mathematical problem under investigation is that of the motion of the interface separating a two- or three-dimensional, inviscid, incompressible, and irrotational fluid, under the influence of gravity, from a region of zero density, neglecting the effects of surface tension. The questions the principal investigator seeks to answer focus on the later-time behavior of surface waves in the open ocean for initially small wave disturbances. In particular, her primary objectives are (1) to identify those initial data that lead to finite time blow-up of the interface and to understand the nature of the singularities that develop in the interface and (2) to identify the largest set of initial data that lead to situations in which blow-up is avoided for all time. The principal investigator also seeks to justify rigorously the modulation approximations of the two- and three-dimensional water wave problems.

Rogue waves are relatively large surface waves that are observed in deep ocean waters. Often appearing in perfectly clear weather without warning, they are blamed for the damage and inexplicable disappearance of numerous large ships and ocean liners. With the resolution of the questions under study in this project, the principal investigator hopes to provide insights into effective designs of computational and laboratory simulations of water wave motion and thereby to advance our understanding of the causes of natural phenomena associated with such waves, including the behavior of rogue waves. The analytical tools developed to carry out the research may also serve to shed new light on related problems in mathematical physics. The proposed research will involve graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI's focus during the funding period is to understand the singularities in the water wave motion. It is assumed that the water is inviscid, incompressible and irrotational, and the air has density zero. The question is to understand the motion of the moving interface between the fluid and the vacuum. With the aforementioned assumptions, the effect of the wind and vorticity are neglected. The questions we seek to answer include what are some typical singular behaviors, and whether these singular behaviors are sustainable without the wind blowing on top of it or the currents in the fluid? 


Intellectual merit:
The PI first constructed a self-similar solution to the problem. This self-similar solution has an angled crest with angle no more than 90 degrees, and are concave up on either sides of the crest. This gives an understanding of the local structure of the singularities. The next problem is to understand whether the self-similar solution is stable. In other words, whether it is observable in the water waves. To this end, the PI, in collaboration with her graduate student Rafe Kinsey, studied the interaction of the fluid interface with a vertical rigid and smooth boundary. Our research led us to an a priori estimate in a more general setting. We constructed an energy functional $E(t)$, which is finite when the interface and the velocity field are smooth. More importantly it is also finite when the interface has singularities such as angled crests. In particular, the energy functional is finite for the self-similar solutions the PI constructed in the earlier work. The PI further obtained a local in time existence result and a blow up criteria. Specifically, she showed that for data satisfying $E(0)<\infty$ at the initial time, there is a solution to the water wave problem, with finite energy $E(t)<\infty$, for a time period $[0, T]$, with $T>0$ depending only on $E(0)$; and she also showed that for any smooth initial data, the solution exists and remains smooth, for as long as $E(t)$ remains finite. 


It is well-known that once a wave forms, it can travel long distances. These results show that the phenomena of angled crests in water waves is sustainable, the self-similar behavior is observable without the wind directly blowing on top of the wave. This work has laid the foundation for further understandings of the singularities in the water wave motion. 


Broader impacts:
The project provided partial funding for graduate students Jennifer Beichman, Rafe Kinsey, Siddhant Agrawal and Qingtang Su. Jennifer Beichman has graduated in 2013, Rafe Kinsey has graduated in 2014. Siddhant Agrawal and Qingtang Su both are working on problems related to the project, and has made partial progress.  The PI has given talks in conferences, seminars and summer schools on the work developed in this project.
